                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Arman 1955-1991: A Retrospective, exhibition files, 1989-1993 (inclusive), 1991-1992 (bulk).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This subseries documents "Arman 1955-1991: A Retrospective," exhibited at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston from November 17, 1991 to January 19, 1992. The exhibition was organized by the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston and curated by Alison de Lima Greene, then Associate Curator of 20th-Century art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. This was the first retrospective exhibition in the United States of Arman's work since 1974. Records include exhibition files from the Office of the Registrar, the Curatorial Department and the Office of the Director. The files include: checklists, condition reports and notes; correspondence, including curatorial correspondence with Arman and his archivist; installation notes; lender files; plot plans; press releases and clippings; research files; shipping records; and material related to the traveling exhibition, including venue files of the Detroit Institute of Arts and the Brooklyn Museum. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:78355642</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:DSI-AAA</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Yamasaki, Minoru, 1912-1986,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Harriman, Virginia,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Minoru Yamasaki interview, [ca. 1959 Aug.] [sound recording].</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>An interview of Minoru Yamasaki conducted by Virginia Harriman. Yamasaki discusses his philosophy of architecture; his belief that architecture should be based on human experience; and his design of the Detroit Institute of Arts. Using architectural models present at the interview, Yamasaki discusses several of his architectural projects, including the Conservatory of Music for Oberlin College; the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, it being the first high building built in Detroit in some years, building to convey a sense of upwardness; World Agricultural Fair for India (temporary) opening December 11, 1959, participating with other countries, Trade Fair Building, exhibit entitled "Mala U.S.A." [Mala means fair in Indian], showing a series of different experiences at a country fair; St. Louis Air Terminal; Benjamin Franklin Junior High School; Wayne Education Building; McGregor Building; Daran Air Terminal (Arabia); trying to be consistent in buildings; Gothic arch; learning from the past about qualities one seeks in architecture; being true to technology; Japanese architecture; serene buildings; machine-made buildings; and limiting himself to public buildings. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Minoru Yamasaki interview, [ca. 1959 Aug.] [sound recording].
resource.abstract: An interview of Minoru Yamasaki conducted by Virginia Harriman. Yamasaki discusses his philosophy of architecture; his belief that architecture should be based on human experience; and his design of the Detroit Institute of Arts. Using architectural models present at the interview, Yamasaki discusses several of his architectural projects, including the Conservatory of Music for Oberlin College; the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, it being the first high building built in Detroit in some years, building to convey a sense of upwardness; World Agricultural Fair for India (temporary) opening December 11, 1959, participating with other countries, Trade Fair Building, exhibit entitled "Mala U.S.A." [Mala means fair in Indian], showing a series of different experiences at a country fair; St. Louis Air Terminal; Benjamin Franklin Junior High School; Wayne Education Building; McGregor Building; Daran Air Terminal (Arabia); trying to be consistent in buildings; Gothic arch; learning from the past about qualities one seeks in architecture; being true to technology; Japanese architecture; serene buildings; machine-made buildings; and limiting himself to public buildings.
resource.extent: Sound recording, master: 1 sound tape reel ; 7 in.Transcript: 33 p.Sound recording, duplicate: 2 sound discs ; 4 3/4 in.
resource.displayEntry: Yamasaki, Minoru, 1912-1986,. Minoru Yamasaki interview, [ca. 1959 Aug.] [sound recording].

                     <namePart>Ferry family.</namePart>
                     <role>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Ferry, Dexter Mason, 1833-1907.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Ferry, Dexter Mason, 1872-1959.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hooker, Blanche Ferry.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Mason, Darius.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Ferry family (Dexter Ferry) papers, 1758-1989 (bulk 1855-1959).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Biographical and genealogical papers; files relating to business and real estate interests, notably the Ferry Seed Company (later Ferry-Morse Seed Company), and the National Pin Company; files relating to family's Republican Party activities, especially Dexter M. Ferry's 1900 Michigan gubernatorial campaign, and the work of Dexter M. Ferry as member of the Michigan House of Representatives, 1901-1904; and papers detailing numerous family philanthropic concerns, mainly with the Detroit Institute of Art. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Michigan</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: Biographical and genealogical papers; files relating to business and real estate interests, notably the Ferry Seed Company (later Ferry-Morse Seed Company), and the National Pin Company; files relating to family's Republican Party activities, especially Dexter M. Ferry's 1900 Michigan gubernatorial campaign, and the work of Dexter M. Ferry as member of the Michigan House of Representatives, 1901-1904; and papers detailing numerous family philanthropic concerns, mainly with the Detroit Institute of Art.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:122545627</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:US-SNAC</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Covensky, Helen Ciesla, 1925-2007.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Helen Covensky papers, 1942-1981.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Biographical data; ca. 120 catalogs; clippings; four files on exhibitions at the Detroit Institute of Art, Lim Art Gallery in Tel-Aviv, Livingstone-Learmouth Gallery in New York City, and London Arts Gallery in Detroit, containing letters, receipts for works of art, loan agreements, price lists, exhibition announcements, newspaper and magazine clippings, press releases, bulletins, and photographs of works of art; miscellany; and photographs of Covensky, her family and friends, her studios in Jerusalem and Detroit, exhibition openings and works of art. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Correspondence with Paul Philippe Cret, 1919-1933.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence concerns the Detroit Institute of Arts, Work No. 105. Correspondents comprise Albert Kahn, Clyde H. Burroughs, Ralph H. Booth, Edsel Ford, and W. H. Valentiner. File includes a copy of a letter from Mary Soper Pope to Booth. Cret conducted most of this correspondence on behalf of himself and his associated firm, Zantzinger, Borie and Medary. Later correspondence discusses the frescos Diego Rivera painted on the walls of the museum's courtyard garden. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Pennsylvania Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>

resource.abstract: Correspondence concerns the Detroit Institute of Arts, Work No. 105. Correspondents comprise Albert Kahn, Clyde H. Burroughs, Ralph H. Booth, Edsel Ford, and W. H. Valentiner. File includes a copy of a letter from Mary Soper Pope to Booth. Cret conducted most of this correspondence on behalf of himself and his associated firm, Zantzinger, Borie and Medary. Later correspondence discusses the frescos Diego Rivera painted on the walls of the museum's courtyard garden.

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Research papers on eighteenth-century French decorative arts, created or compiled by Henry Hawley. The material primarily relates to the cabinetmaker Jean-Pierre Latz, but also includes research on the Dodge collection of eighteenth-century art at the Detroit Institute of Arts, together with research on clocks, and research regarding William Beckford. Collection includes handwritten notes, scholarly correspondence, photographic documentation, typescripts, catalogs, journals, and printed ephemera. </abstract>
                  <name>

                     <role>
